Configuration.Description: Non-syndromic cryptorchidism is a common malformation, but the genetic loci that increase susceptibility to cryptorchidism remain unknown. A genome-wide association study (GWAS) was completed to determine whether common allelic variants are associated with susceptibility to cryptorchidism. Two sets of discovery groups were genotyped. Group 1 (559 cases and 1772 controls) was genotyped with HumanHap550v1.0, HumanHap550v3.0 or Human610-quad v1.0. Group 2 (353 cases and 1149 controls) was genotyped with HumanOmniExpress-12v1 or HumanOmniExpress-12v1-1. The sample and marker QCs were performed separately using PLINK (v1.07; http://pngu.mgh.harvard.edu/purcell/plink/) and logistic regression analyses were performed with first and second multidimensional scaling (MDS) components as covariates.
Configuration.StudyInEx: Cases were unrelated Caucasian non-syndromic cryptorchidism patients. Exclusion criteria included multiple congenital anomalies; diagnosis of a syndrome; presence of other genital anomalies such as hypospadias, chordee or other penile anomalies; abdominal wall defects or syndromic urogenital malformation sequences. Controls were Caucasian males ≥ 7 years with no known history of testicular disease, and without penile anomaly, diagnosis of a syndrome or any additional medical disorder associated with cryptorchidism.

ParticipantSet.UseLimitation: Use of the data must be related to Cryptorchidism. Requestor agrees to make results of studies using the data available to the larger scientific community. Requestor must provide a letter of collaboration with the primary study investigator(s). Use of the data is limited to not-for-profit organizations. Use of the data is limited to genetic studies only.

Analysis.Description: Purpose of the analysis: Nonsyndromic cryptorchidism is a common malformation with familial aggregation suggesting genetic susceptibility. The genetic loci that contribute to cryptorchidism remain unknown; however, human and animal pedigrees and our linkage analysis of the cryptorchid orl rat strain support polygenic inheritance. Platforms and sample size: Two sets of sample groups were genotyped. One group (559 cases and 1772 controls) was genotyped with HumanHap550v1.0, HumanHap550v v3.0 or Human610-quad v1.0. The other group (353 cases and 1149 controls) was genotyped with HumanOmniExpress-12v1 or HumanOmniExpress-12v1-1. Phenotype trait: nonsyndromic cryptorchidism.

Purpose of the analysis: Nonsyndromic cryptorchidism is a common malformation with familial aggregation suggesting genetic susceptibility. The genetic loci that contribute to cryptorchidism remain unknown; however, human and animal pedigrees and our linkage analysis of the cryptorchid orl rat strain support polygenic inheritance. Platforms and sample size: Two sets of sample groups were genotyped. One group (559 cases and 1772 controls) was genotyped with HumanHap550v1.0, HumanHap550v v3.0 or Human610-quad v1.0. The other group (353 cases and 1149 controls) was genotyped with HumanOmniExpress-12v1 or HumanOmniExpress-12v1-1. Phenotype trait: nonsyndromic cryptorchidism.
